results.title: Teenagers Aren’t Getting Enough Exercise at School, or Anywhere
results.abstract: Teenagers can be a notoriously sedentary group. Now a new study showed that school may be a big part of the problem.

multimedia.caption: Teenagers get less exercise than almost any other age group, a new study shows.
multimedia.copyright: Jake Michaels for The New York Times

results.title: Does Exercise Help Keep Our Brains Young?
results.abstract: Physical fitness may be critical for maintaining a relatively youthful and nimble brain as we age, according to a new study of brain activation patterns in older people.

results.title: U.S. Reports a New Low in Deaths of Infants
results.abstract: The rate of infant deaths fell more than 13 percent from 2005 to 2013 and by 2.3 percent in 2014, but the United States still has one of the highest rates among the richest nations.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: A decline in preterm births helped drive infant mortality to a new low in 2014, the C.D.C. says.
A decline in preterm births helped drive infant mortality to a new low in 2014, the C.D.C. says.

results.title: Blood Pressure, the Top and Bottom Numbers
results.abstract: While high systolic (the top number) and diastolic (the bottom number) readings are both associated with increased risk, they may present different risks for different diseases.

results.title: They Helped Erase Ebola in Liberia. Now Liberia Is Erasing Them.
results.abstract: Thirty young men spent months burning the bodies of the infected. A year later, many relatives and fellow countrymen still can’t forgive them.

multimedia.caption: Sherdrick Koffa, estranged from his family because he helped burn bodies during the Ebola outbreak.

results.title: Marco Rubio Quietly Undermines Affordable Care Act
results.abstract: A provision slipped into a 2014 spending law by the Florida senator has tangled up the Obama administration and sent tremors through health insurance markets.
des_facet: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

multimedia.caption: Senator Marco Rubio at a campaign event in Greenland, N.H., last week. He attached a provision limiting how much the government can spend to protect insurance companies against financial losses to a spending law last year.
multimedia.copyright: Ian Thomas Jansen-Lonnquist for The New York Times

results.title: Americans Who Don’t Buy Health Coverage Face Heftier Fine in ’16, Analysis Finds
results.abstract: Americans who remain uninsured in 2016 despite having the option of buying health coverage through an Affordable Care Act marketplace will owe an average tax penalty of $969 per household.
des_facet: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

results.title: CPR Survival Rates Can Differ Greatly by City
results.abstract: Improvements remain underused in practice. As a result, survival rates after cardiac arrest vary as much as 500 percent across the country.

multimedia.caption: Dr. Sam Parnia, the director of resuscitation research at Stony Brook Hospital, compared CPR to driving an outdated automobile.
multimedia.copyright: Uli Seit for The New York Times

results.title: Chipotle’s Safety Woes Worsen as Scores of Students Fall Ill in Boston
results.abstract: Chipotle Mexican Grill’s stock continued to fall after worries about food safety spread to Boston, where 80 college students got sick after eating at one of its restaurants.

multimedia.caption: A Chipotle restaurant near Boston College was temporarily closed after 80 students reported getting sick after eating there.
A Chipotle restaurant near Boston College was temporarily closed after 80 students reported getting sick after eating there.

results.title: Smog So Thick, Beijing Comes to a Standstill
results.abstract: The poisonous air quality prompted the government to declare a “red alert,” closing schools, forcing motorists to stay off the road and shutting factories.

multimedia.caption: A building with a screen on it in Beijing on Tuesday was obscured by smog that led to the city’s top level of air pollution warning.
A building with a screen on it in Beijing on Tuesday was obscured by smog that led to the city’s top level of air pollution warning.

results.title: Prostate Cancer Treatment Tied to Alzheimer’s Risk
results.abstract: Hormone therapy, a common treatment for prostate cancer, is associated with an increased risk for Alzheimer’s disease, a new study has found.

results.title: False Positive Breast Tests Tied to Increased Cancer Risk
results.abstract: Women with a false-positive mammogram or breast biopsy result have an increased risk of breast cancer over the next 10 years compared with those with a true negative result, a new report has found.

results.title: Distracted Walkers Pose Threat to Self and Others
results.abstract: Injuries resulting from distracted walking — using a cellphone while walking — have increased in parallel with the increase in cellphone use.

results.title: Health Quiz: Beer, Prunes and Jogging
results.abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

results.title: Penis Transplants Being Planned to Help Wounded Troops
results.abstract: For young men maimed in combat, surgeons at Johns Hopkins hope to ease a rarely discussed injury with an operation that has never been performed in the United States.

results.title: Overweight at 18 and at Greater Risk for Sudden Death
results.abstract: Women who were overweight at age 18 are at increased risk for sudden cardiac death, no matter what their current weight is, a new study reports.

results.title: The Tricky Business of Treating Altitude Sickness
results.abstract: Mountain visitors are being offered oxygen therapies, oils, pills and more that claim to prevent altitude sickness, but there is little research to prove they work.

multimedia.caption: Snowy peaks of the Weminuche Wilderness mountains in San Juan National Forest, in western Colorado. Thin air can cause headaches, nausea, fatigue, dizziness and worse.
Snowy peaks of the Weminuche Wilderness mountains in San Juan National Forest, in western Colorado. Thin air can cause headaches, nausea, fatigue, dizziness and worse.

results.title: Hawaii’s Dengue Fever Outbreak Grows
results.abstract: Health authorities in Hawaii’s Big Island have confirmed 139 cases, and a federal health official said the outbreak could last for months.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: The Asian Tiger mosquito is contributing to the spread of the dengue fever outbreak in Hawaii.
The Asian Tiger mosquito is contributing to the spread of the dengue fever outbreak in Hawaii.

results.title: ‘The Boy in the Bubble’ Moved a World He Couldn’t Touch
results.abstract: The life and death of David Phillip Vetter, born in 1971 without a functioning immune system, contributed to medical advances that give hope to the once-hopeless.

results.title: Fathers May Pass Down More Than Just Genes, Study Suggests
results.abstract: Recent research suggests that experience may alter a man’s sperm, and the changes may be handed down to his children.

multimedia.caption: Scientists are investigating the epigenetics of fatherhood: how a man’s experiences can alter his sperm, and whether those changes in turn may alter his children.
Scientists are investigating the epigenetics of fatherhood: how a man’s experiences can alter his sperm, and whether those changes in turn may alter his children.

results.title: Skinnier and Chillier
results.abstract: Feeling cold more often after losing weight probably has to do with a loss of insulating body fat, but medical problems could also be a factor.

results.title: Caregivers Sometimes Must Sacrifice Their Careers
results.abstract: Family members caring for older adults struggle to balance work demands, yet paid leave is mandatory in just three states. That may be changing.
org_facet: Community Service Society of New York

results.title: Delhi to Limit Use of Cars in an Effort to Control Pollution
results.abstract: As of Jan. 1, the authorities will limit the use of private cars in the Indian capital to every other day, depending on whether a vehicle’s license plate ends in an even or odd number.

results.title: Data Storage on DNA Can Keep It Safe for Centuries
results.abstract: Scientists have shown that DNA molecules can be the basis for a long-term storage system potentially capable of holding all of the world’s digital information in a tiny space.

multimedia.caption: From left, Luis Ceze, one of the designers of the new DNA storage system; Douglas Carmean, a designer of computers at Microsoft; and Karin Strauss, a Microsoft computer architect, at the University of Washington in Seattle.
multimedia.copyright: David Ryder for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: From left, Luis Ceze, one of the designers of the new DNA storage system; Douglas Carmean, a designer of computers at Microsoft; and Karin Strauss, a Microsoft computer architect, at the University of Washington in Seattle.
multimedia.copyright: David Ryder for The New York Times

results.title: Tylenol Is Ineffective Against Flu Symptoms
results.abstract: Tylenol had no discernible effect on reducing fever or other symptoms of flu, researches found.

results.title: Think Like a Doctor: Limp as a Baby Solved
results.abstract: Readers solve the real-life case of a 28-year-old woman who had a long history of abdominal pain and constipation who suddenly started having seizures and hallucinations.

results.title: Living With Cancer: Hurry Up and Wait
results.abstract: Hurrying up to wait is, of course, the fate of most patients. But for cancer patients, waiting entails being enveloped in heightened fears about harmful protocols and the difficulty of eradicating or containing the disease.

results.title: TV May Be Bad for Your Brain
results.abstract: Watching television may be bad for your brain, a new study suggests.

results.title: Think Like a Doctor: Limp as a Baby
results.abstract: Can you figure out what is wrong with a 28-year-old woman who, over the course of weeks, becomes completely debilitated by abdominal pain, profound weakness and seizures?

multimedia.caption: An M.R.I. of the patient's brain; the circled area of brightness is some of the swelling that caused seizures, confusion and hallucinations.
An M.R.I. of the patient's brain; the circled area of brightness is some of the swelling that caused seizures, confusion and hallucinations.

results.title: Running With Osteoporosis
results.abstract: Running prompts bones to become denser and stronger — but it is hard to know whether someone with mild osteoporosis should run.
